answer:
**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis**  
• **Frame 1:** The camera is centered in a single through‐lane in each direction with a solid double‐yellow centerline. A traffic signal ahead is green; there is no sign or marking indicating “No Left Turn” or “Left Turn Only on Arrow.”  
• **Frame 2:** An oncoming car is visible in the opposite lane but there is still no indication of any left‐turn‐only arrow or prohibition. No “One Way” signage is apparent at the cross street.  
• **Frame 3:** The oncoming car passes by. Still no posted sign that would forbid a left turn or require waiting for a dedicated green arrow.  
• **Frame 4:** Approaching the intersection, you can see the crosswalk and standard overhead signals; there is no “Left Turn Signal Only” sign or additional left‐turn arrow.  
• **Frame 5:** The intersection is fully visible. The signals remain the standard circular green lights, with no restriction signage on the mast arms.  

**Contextual Reasoning**  
Since there is no signage stipulating “No Left Turn,” no indication the cross street is one‐way in the wrong direction, and no separate left‐turn signal that must be awaited, a conventional unprotected left turn (i.e., yield to oncoming traffic) appears both legal and (provided you yield appropriately) safe.  

**Match to Answer Choices**  
• **A. No it’s a one way going right.** – There is no indication the cross street is a one‐way.  
• **B. No we have to wait for left turn signal.** – The overhead lights are standard greens, and there is no posted requirement that left turns must have a protected arrow.  
• **C. No there is oncoming traffic.** – While there was an oncoming vehicle earlier, one can legally wait for traffic to clear and then turn. That does not make the left turn itself illegal.  
• **D. Yes it is legal and safe.** – Absent prohibitive signs or special signals, and once oncoming traffic is clear, the turn is legally and safely permitted.  

<answer>D</answer>
